1.subquestion: Show that if $r > 0,$ then $r$ belongs to S.

subanswer.text: By Descartes' rule of signs, since $P(X)=X^4+AX^3+BX^2+CX+D=0$ ($A<0$) has three sign changes (i.e., alternating positive/negative coefficients), it follows that either no roots or precisely three distinct complex nonreal roots exist; but clearly neither case applies here because $|C|=-|\sin A|$ implies $|\sin A|=|C|,$ which forces some solution other than zero as well as its reflection about X axis through line OY. 0.user_question:
Let $S$ be the set of points $(a,b)$ with $0 \le a,$ $b \le 1$ such that the equation
\[x^4 + ax^3 - bx^2 + ax + 1 = 0\]has at least one real root.  Determine the area of the graph of $S.$

1.subquestion: Show that if $r_i > 0$ ($i=1,...,n$) satisfy $$|q+r_1+\cdots+r_{i-1}|<p$$then $|q|$ must also satisfy $$|q|\ge |p-r_1-\cdots-r_{i-1}|.$$

0.user_question:
Let $S$ be the set of points $(a,b)$ with $0 \le a,$ $b \le 1$ such that the equation
\[x^4 + ax^3 - bx^2 + ax + 1 = 0\]has at least one real root.  Determine the area of the graph of $S.$

ost_step.1: By Vieta's formulas, any quartic polynomial of the form \[ax^4 + bx^3 + cx^2 + dx + e = 0\]where \(e\) is nonzero satisfies \[\frac{-d}{a} = r_1r_2r_3 + s_1r_1s_2 + s_1r_2s_2 + t_1t_2,\]where \(r_i,s_i,t_i\) are roots of the polynomial and \(\text{degree}(p)\) denotes degree of polynomials.\[\begin{aligned}{\operatorname{degree}}( p )&= 4 \\r_1 + r_2 + r_3 + s_1 + s_2 + t_1 &= -\frac ba\\r_1r_2 + rs_2 + sr_2 + st_1 + tr_2 + ts_1 &= \frac cb \\r_1rs_2st_1&=\frac ed=-\frac cda=-1 . \end{aligned}\]In particular, because our quadratic doesn't contain constant term equal to zero (\(\frac d {a}=1\)), every permutation of distinct reals

direct_answer.text:
Let's think step by step. Consider the equations obtained by setting each variable ($a$, $b$) as the independent variables while keeping the other fixed within [0,1]:
Firstly consider when fixing $a$: $$f(a,b)=\left\{ x^4+ax^3-bx^2+ax+1=0 \right\} \quad \Rightarrow \quad f'_b:\mathbb R\to \{0\}\subset \mathbb R,$$the derivative of $f$ wrt $b$, vanishes exactly once inside $[0,1]$ since it changes sign twice; similarly considering $b$ first yields another critical value. Hence either both or none of them lie outside $[0,1]$. If neither lies outside, let those not contained directly correspond via linear transformation onto interval without overlapping part lying above/below coordinate axes i.e., map left boundary into right axis intersection ([c,1]) so solution region becomes convex polygon bounded by intersections pairs $(\pm k_{k},m)$,$(h,u)$ whence area computable using standard methods.
